Kristinn Sigurdsson wrote:

> Stack, this sounds like an interesting approach and matches up well 
> with what I've been thinking.
>  
> What communications layer would you be using?

'[ 1302205 ] new alreadyIncluded option: remote to process/machine' 
(https://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1302205&group_id=73833&atid=539102) 
has current thinking on the matter.

St.Ack

>  
> - Kris
>
>     -----Original Message-----
>     *From:* archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
>     [mailto:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com] *On Behalf Of *stack
>     *Sent:* 9. nï¿½vember 2005 22:06
>     *To:* archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
>     *Subject:* Re: [archive-crawler] Handling identical documents from
>     different sites.
>
>     callforshadab wrote:
>
>     > How should this be handled in the clustered version (multiple
>     machines
>     > running Heritrix)?
>     >
>     What would you suggest?
>
>     One notion we've been kicking around is having a fast and dumb server
>     sitting in the middle of a coordinated crawling cluster.  A processor
>     hosted by alll machines would ask it if the content (hash) had
>     already
>     been seen. Such a server might also be used to check if an URL is
>     already-seen.  Though the crawl space is split between crawlers, we
>     might run a central server to guard against repeat fetches when
>     queues
>     are moved between machines, either because one machine is
>     overloaded so
>     we narrow range its responsible for off-loading to adjacent
>     crawlers or
>     because a crawler is picking up for a crashed crawler (If I remember
>     correctly, the ubicrawler folks in their paper allow that a few
>     URLs may
>     be mutiply fetched during the coming and going of crawlers flux).
>
>     St.Ack
>
